name: Gudi Padwa
description: Gudi Padwa marks the beginning of the New Year according to the Hindu calendar. It symbolizes the victory of good over evil and the arrival of spring.
how_to_celebrate: Decorate your home with a Gudi (flag), wear new clothes, prepare traditional Maharashtrian dishes, and visit temples. Outside India, you can celebrate by cooking traditional foods, decorating with rangoli, and connecting with the Marathi community.
significance: New Year celebration and spring festival

name: Diwali
description: The Festival of Lights, celebrating the victory of light over darkness and good over evil. It commemorates Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya.
how_to_celebrate: Light diyas and candles, decorate with rangoli, exchange gifts, burst firecrackers (responsibly), and share sweets. Outside India, focus on lighting diyas, making rangoli with colored rice, and sharing traditional sweets with neighbors.

name: Holi
description: The Festival of Colors, celebrating the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil. It's a time for joy, forgiveness, and new beginnings.
how_to_celebrate: Play with colors, dance to traditional music, share sweets, and forgive past grievances. Outside India, use natural colors, organize community events, and share traditional foods with friends.
significance: Spring festival and victory of good over evil

name: Pola
description: A festival dedicated to bulls and cattle, celebrating their importance in agriculture. Farmers worship their bulls and decorate them beautifully.
how_to_celebrate: Decorate bulls with ornaments, prepare traditional foods, and participate in bull races. Outside India, you can celebrate by learning about agricultural traditions and preparing traditional Maharashtrian dishes.

name: Navratri
description: Nine nights dedicated to the worship of Goddess Durga in her various forms. It's a time of fasting, prayer, and celebration.
how_to_celebrate: Fast for nine days, perform Garba and Dandiya dances, visit temples, and offer prayers to Goddess Durga. Outside India, participate in community Garba events and maintain the fasting tradition.

name: Dussehra
description: Celebrates the victory of Lord Rama over Ravana, symbolizing the triumph of good over evil. It marks the end of Navratri.
how_to_celebrate: Watch Ramlila performances, burn effigies of Ravana, exchange sweets, and visit temples. Outside India, organize community events, share traditional foods, and tell the story of Ramayana to children.

name: Ganesh Chaturthi
description: Celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha, the remover of obstacles. It's one of the most popular festivals in Maharashtra.
how_to_celebrate: Install Ganesha idols at home, perform daily prayers, prepare modaks, and participate in processions. Outside India, you can celebrate by setting up a small Ganesha idol, making modaks, and organizing community prayers.

name: Krishna Janmashtami
description: Celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna, the eighth avatar of Vishnu. It's marked by fasting, prayers, and devotional songs.
how_to_celebrate: Fast until midnight, perform Krishna Puja, sing devotional songs, and break pots filled with curd. Outside India, maintain the fasting tradition, perform puja at home, and share traditional foods with the community.

name: Raksha Bandhan
description: A festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters tie rakhi on their brothers' wrists as a symbol of protection.
how_to_celebrate: Sisters tie rakhi on brothers' wrists, exchange gifts, share sweets, and pray for each other's well-being. Outside India, you can celebrate by sending rakhis to brothers, organizing virtual celebrations, and sharing traditional sweets.

name: Karva Chauth
description: A festival where married women fast for the long life and well-being of their husbands. It's celebrated with great devotion and love.
how_to_celebrate: Women fast from sunrise to moonrise, perform puja, listen to Karva Chauth stories, and break fast after seeing the moon. Outside India, maintain the fasting tradition and organize community celebrations.

name: Makar Sankranti
description: Celebrates the transition of the sun into the zodiac sign of Capricorn. It marks the end of winter and the beginning of longer days.
how_to_celebrate: Fly kites, eat sesame-based sweets, take holy dips in rivers, and share traditional foods. Outside India, you can celebrate by making traditional sweets, flying kites, and sharing the significance of the festival with children.

name: Rath Yatra
description: The Chariot Festival of Lord Jagannath, where the deities are taken out in grand processions on beautifully decorated chariots.
how_to_celebrate: Participate in chariot processions, offer prayers, receive prasad, and join devotional singing. Outside India, you can celebrate by organizing community prayers, sharing traditional foods, and learning about the significance of the festival.

name: Onam
description: A harvest festival of Kerala celebrating the return of King Mahabali. It's marked by grand feasts, traditional dances, and flower decorations.
how_to_celebrate: Prepare Onam Sadya (grand feast), create Pookalam (flower rangoli), perform traditional dances, and share the feast with family. Outside India, you can celebrate by preparing traditional Kerala dishes and learning about the legend of King Mahabali.
significance: Harvest festival and King Mahabali's return

name: Baisakhi
description: A harvest festival of Punjab marking the beginning of the new year and the formation of the Khalsa Panth by Guru Gobind Singh.
how_to_celebrate: Visit Gurudwaras, participate in Nagar Kirtan, enjoy langar, and perform traditional dances. Outside India, you can celebrate by visiting local Gurudwaras, participating in community events, and sharing traditional Punjabi foods.

name: Durga Puja
description: A grand festival celebrating Goddess Durga's victory over the demon Mahishasura. It's marked by elaborate decorations, cultural programs, and community celebrations.
how_to_celebrate: Visit beautifully decorated pandals, participate in cultural programs, enjoy bhog, and immerse in the festive atmosphere. Outside India, you can celebrate by organizing community pujas, preparing traditional Bengali dishes, and participating in cultural events.
